metadata.case_name: M/s. K. S. Rashid & Son and Rashid Ahmad v. Income-tax Authorities; M/s. Bhawani Prasad Girdharlal v. Income-tax Authorities
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 37-40 of 1963; Civil Appeal No. 589 of 1963; Writ Petitions Nos. 335-345 of 1960

facts.text: M/s. K. S. Rashid & Son and partner Rashid Ahmad filed writ petitions Nos. 870-873 of 1956 in Allahabad High Court challenging notices served under s.34(1A) of Income-tax Act, 1922 for income years 1941-42 to 1946-47.
Allahabad High Court dismissed writ petitions Nos. 870-873 and 349 of 1956 by judgment dated August 13/11, 1959; appeals to Supreme Court with certificate.

M/s. K. S. Rashid & Son and Rashid Ahmad filed Writ Petitions Nos. 335-345 of 1960 in Supreme Court under Art.32 challenging notices served on 19th March 1956 and excess profit tax order under s.34(1A).
M/s. Bhawani Prasad Girdharlal filed writ petition in Allahabad High Court challenging notice issued on 16th August 1955 under s.34(1A); dismissed, appeal No.589/1963 with certificate.
s.34(1A) introduced by amendment on 17th July 1954 following Supreme Court striking down s.54 of Taxation on Income (Investigation Commission) Act, 1947 in Suraj Mall Mohta case on 28th May 1954.
Supreme Court in Shree Meenakshi Mills Ltd. held s.51 of Investigation Commission Act contravened Art.14 after enactment of s.34(1A), making s.51 a dead letter.

s.34(1A) applies to cases where Income-tax Officer has reason to believe income escaped assessment for years with previous year 1st Sept 1939 to 31st March 1946, amounting to Rs.1 lakh or more, notwithstanding 8/4 year limitation in s.34(1).
Proviso to s.34(1A): ITO shall not issue notice unless records reasons and Central Board of Revenue satisfied; no notice after 31st March 1956.
In C.A. No.589/1963, appellant assumed reasons recorded but claimed entitled to copy; respondent affirmed reasons recorded.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.34(1A) of Income-tax Act, 1922 is ultra vires and contravenes Art.14 of Constitution due to denial of appeal/remedy available under s.34(1) and absence of limitation period.
Construction of s.34(1A): Whether notice under it deemed notice under s.22(2), making appeal provisions (ss.30,31,32,33,33A,33B) and s.23 procedure applicable.
Whether proviso to s.34(1A) condition precedent satisfied in C.A. No.589/1963.

petitioner_arguments.text: s.34(1A) denies remedies of appeal and revision available under ss.30,31,32,33,33A,33B to assessees under s.34(1), amounting to preferential treatment and discrimination under Art.14.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.14 of Constitution; omission of 'as if the notice were a notice issued under that sub-section' from s.34(1)

petitioner_arguments.text: No period of limitation under s.34(1A) unlike 8 years under s.34(1)(a), discriminating against similarly placed assessees.
Proviso to s.34(1A) not satisfied as no reasons recorded or copy provided to assessee.

respondent_arguments.text: s.34(1A) valid; notice refers to s.22(2) requirements, provisions of Act apply 'thereupon' including appeals; omission not deliberate.
Rational classification: s.34(1A) for war period (1939-1946) high escaped income (Rs.1 lakh+), justifying no limitation.
Reasons recorded as per proviso in C.A.589/1963; assessee not entitled to copy.

court_reasoning.text: s.34(1A) notice contains requirements of s.22(2) notice; 'thereupon' provisions of Act apply so far as may be, including s.23 procedure and appeals ss.30-33B; omission of deeming clause not significant as s.34(1) from 1948, s.34(1A) 1954.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature intended to provide same remedies as s.34(1) to remove infirmity of struck-down s.54.

court_reasoning.text: Rational classification under Art.14: s.34(1A) limited to 1939-1946 war profits period, escaped income Rs.1 lakh+, nexus to object of recovering large escaped income.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Smaller class with higher stakes justifies differential treatment including no limitation.

court_reasoning.text: Overlapping years immaterial as procedure and remedies same under either section.
Proviso satisfied; pleadings assume reasons recorded, dispute only on copy which not pressed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant cannot now claim no reasons recorded.

holdings.text: s.34(1A) valid, does not contravene Art.14; appeals/remedies available; rational classification upheld.
Notice under s.34(1A) attracts s.22(2), s.23 and appeal provisions of Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Suraj Mall Mohta and Another v. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri and Another
precedents_cited.relevance: Struck down s.54 of Investigation Commission Act as less favourable than s.34(1), violating Art.14; led to enactment of s.34(1A).

precedents_cited.case_name: Shree Meenakshi Mills Ltd., Madurai v. Sri A. V. Viswanatha Sastri and Another
precedents_cited.relevance: Struck down s.51 of Investigation Commission Act post s.34(1A) as contravening Art.14.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jai Kishan Srivastava v. Income-tax Officer, Kanpur and Another
precedents_cited.relevance: Allahabad High Court majority upheld validity of s.34(1A).

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Core provisions for escaped assessment; s.34(1A) upheld as applying other provisions including appeals.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: s.34(1A) does not discriminate; writs under Art.32.

outcome.summary: All Civil Appeals (Nos.37-40/1963, 589/1963) and Writ Petitions (Nos.335-345/1960) dismissed; s.34(1A) held valid and not contravening Art.14.

key_quotes.text: "the legislature must have presumably wanted to afford to the assessees in respect of whom s.34(1A) was intended to be invoked, the same remedies that were available to the assessee covered by s.34(1)".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for construing appeals as available under s.34(1A).

key_quotes.text: "s.34(1A) is intended to deal with assessees whose income has escaped assessment during a specified period between 1st of September, 1939 and the 31st of March, 1946... escaped income is likely to amount to Rs.1 lakh or more."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "we must hold that s.34(1A) is valid and has not contravened Art.14 of the Constitution."
key_quotes.speaker: court
